Physics (Properties of Matter).subject: Physics (Properties of Matter)
Physics (Properties of Matter).question: The spring constant of a spring depends on its
options: thickness, its diameter and its material
Physics (Properties of Matter).answer: thickness, its diameter and its material
Physics (Properties of Matter).explanation: F = – kx; k = spring constant and it measures stiffness or softness of spring. Hence. K depends on length, radius and material of the spring.

Physics (Electronics).subject: Physics (Electronics)
Physics (Electronics).question: In a bipolar junction transistor
options: all the three regions (the emitter, , the base and the collector) have equal concentrations of impurity
the emitter has the least concentration of impurity
the collector has the least concentration of impurity
the base has the least concentration of impurity
Physics (Electronics).answer: all the three regions (the emitter, , the base and the collector) have equal concentrations of impurity
Physics (Electronics).explanation: A Bipolar Junction Transistor, or BJT, is a solid-state device in which the current flow between two terminals (the collector and the emitter) is controlled by the amount of current that flows through a third terminal (the base).

Physics (Units & Measurements).subject: Physics (Units & Measurements)
Physics (Units & Measurements).question: The pressure exerted by a 760 mm column of mercury at 0°C is known as
Physics (Units & Measurements).explanation: 76cm Hg = 760 mmHg = 1 atm = 101325 Pa (mmHg = milimeters of mercury) (atm = atmosphere) (Pa = Pascal = N/m2, SI unit for pressure)

Physics (Units & Measurements).subject: Physics (Units & Measurements)
Physics (Units & Measurements).question: Which one of the following physical quantities has the same dimensions as that of Planck's constant h?
Physics (Units & Measurements).explanation: The dimension of Plank's contant can be obtained from any of the equations in which it appears, e.g. h = E/n, l = h/p, etc. Planck's Constant h = 6.626176 × 10–34 joule-second = 6.626176 × 10–34 m2 kg/s. [h] = [M L2 T–1]. Angular momentum l = r × p. [l] = [r] [p] = [L] [M L T–1] = [M L2 T–1]. Both the Planck's constant and angular momentum have the same dimensions.

Physics (Optics).subject: Physics (Optics)
Physics (Optics).question: In total internal reflection, the light travels from
options: rarer to denser medium and it occurs with no loss of intensity
denser to rarer medium and it occurs with no loss of intensity
rarer to denser medium and it occurs with loss of intensity
denser to rarer medium and it occurs with loss of intensity
Physics (Optics).answer: denser to rarer medium and it occurs with no loss of intensity

Physics (Optics).subject: Physics (Optics)
Physics (Optics).question: Light travels in a straight line (rectilinear propagation of light). This statement does hold if the medium of travel for light is
options: made up of slabs of different refractive indices

Physics (Modern Physics).subject: Physics (Modern Physics)
Physics (Modern Physics).question: The energy of a photon, whose momentum is 10 MeV/ c, where c is the speed of light, is given by
Physics (Modern Physics).explanation: As per the formula Energy of Photon is always equal to the multiple of the Momentum and Speed of light. Therefore; P=E/C Where P is Momentum, E is Energy and C is Speed of Light. 10 MeV/C=E/C; {P (Momentum) = 10MeV/C; as given in Question}. E= 10 MeV

Physics (Electricity & Magnetism).subject: Physics (Electricity & Magnetism)
Physics (Electricity & Magnetism).question: Liquids and gases never show
Physics (Electricity & Magnetism).explanation: Liquids and gases show diamagnetic, paramagnetic and electromagnetic property, but it never show ferromagnetic property.
